image.altText: A close up shot of police tape with cars parked on a street and trees blurred in the background

items.synopsis: Detectives appeal for information after a man allegedly approached a 12-year-old girl in Warnbro on Monday and grabbed her shirt before she managed to escape.

title.children: Police investigating reports of second alleged attempted child abduction in Perth's southern suburbs

image.altText: US gun violence

items.synopsis: Serious family and domestic violence offenders will not be able to own firearms or gun licences under the latest element of sweeping gun reform by the WA government.

title.children: Firearms and gun licence ban for DV offenders to be strengthened in response to spate of WA deaths

image.altText: An elderly woman holds up a small poster that reads 'vote no', as part of a rally for the Indigenous Voice to Parliament.

items.synopsis: The No campaign has been accused of asking volunteers to spread "fear and misinformation" in an effort to convince referendum voters of its agenda.

title.children: Voice No campaign accused of asking volunteers to 'flat out lie'

image.altText: An AFL player in a black training shirt, catches a football

items.synopsis: Maynard's season will be over if Collingwood is unable to throw out the defender's ban for rough conduct. Follow live.

title.children: 'Thought I'd be able to smother': Brayden Maynard offers defence at tribunal for hit that left Dees star concussed

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Magpies defender says he understands the charge. He says he remembers the incident but says it happened "very very quickly". "Angus Brayshaw came out of the front of the stoppage," he says. "I decided to hover a bit ... " "He was coming forward, I decided to try and smother the ball." Maynard says he tried to smother because he believed he would be able to have an impact and smother the ball. He says he jumped straight up. Asked how far away Brayshaw was when he was about to kick, Maynard says "a fair way away, but I thought I'd be able to smother the ball". He says he was not close enough to tackle, or to smother the ball while standing.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Brayden Maynard to give evidence

children.content: The Magpies defender says he understands the charge.
He says he remembers the incident but says it happened "very very quickly".
"Angus Brayshaw came out of the front of the stoppage," he says.
"I decided to hover a bit ... "
"He was coming forward, I decided to try and smother the ball."
Maynard says he tried to smother because he believed he would be able to have an impact and smother the ball.
He says he jumped straight up.
Asked how far away Brayshaw was when he was about to kick, Maynard says "a fair way away, but I thought I'd be able to smother the ball".
He says he was not close enough to tackle, or to smother the ball while standing.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Brayden Maynard's lawyer, Ben Ihle, says his client is challenging the rough conduct charge, and also challenges the grading of conduct as careless.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Maynard challenges the charge and classification

children.content: Brayden Maynard's lawyer, Ben Ihle, says his client is challenging the rough conduct charge, and also challenges the grading of conduct as careless.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Brayden Maynard's hearing is under way at the AFL Tribunal.

image.altText: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un waves from a private train.

image.altText: An aerial view shows the charred remains of a building, with sparse trees nearby

title.children: Violence is so bad in this PNG community that police sealed it off to outsiders. The ABC got to go inside

image.altText: A woman with a ponytail and dark long sleeve top standing in front of a tree

title.children: Why are even healthy people getting sick with pneumonia this year?

image.altText: Angus Brayshaw is lying on a stretcher with a neck brace on and his eyes closed

image.altText: A pregnant woman in a white dress with a horse on a beach.

image.altText: A pharmacist standing behind a counter holding a prescription basket towards the camera

items.synopsis: Parents and carers are warned that a shortage affecting the most-prescribed antibiotics for children is set to continue until early next year.

title.children: The most-prescribed antibiotics for children are in critically short supply across the country

image.altText: A shot from a boat looking down at a large coral boulder nearly 7 metres across and three people in wetsuits diving it

image.altText: A middle-aged, bespectacled man in a suit exits a court building.

title.children: Former executive avoids conviction over $1.8m TAFE scandal

image.altText: A man stands on a balcony with a frown on his face.

items.synopsis: Insurance companies have responded to back-to-back floods and soaring building costs by hiking premiums by around 30 per cent in just one year. But for the riskiest homes, cover is either refused outright, or offered at prices few can afford.

image.altText: Child's arm dangles while in a car seat.

image.altText: A teenager boy with a surfboard on a beach under an ocean pier

image.altText: A young man wearing a grey hoodie.

image.altText: A mother and father with a child in a wheelchair, and another child on a swing.

items.synopsis: Barely two months ago, Spencer Barton was an active and energetic five-year-old — but a shock diagnosis has turned the lives of him and his parents upside down, and left them battling not only his condition but the health system.

image.altText: A woman in a red hat leaning on a rusty bar of a gate.

items.synopsis: Australia's richest person, Gina Rinehart, has increased her stake in lithium firm Liontown Resources as global lithium giant Albemarle seeks a buyout. Meanwhile, the ASX is trading sideways. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Gina Rinehart ups stake in lithium miner Liontown Resources in looming takeover battle, ASX treads water, consumer confidence falls

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Petrol prices have been climbing as oil prices have increased. CommSec says petrol is up by nearly 23 per cent over the year, and by 16 per cent over the past two months. Although the national average petrol price fell 1.7 cents per litre last week to 201.7 cents a litre. The ACCC today released its latest petrol monitoring report. It says retail petrol prices were stable over the June quarter, rising by 0.7 cents per litre from the March quarter to 182.9 cents a litre. Quarterly average retail petrol prices increased in Canberra, Darwin and Hobart. Average prices across more than 190 regional locations the ACCC monitors were 185.3 cents per litre, up 2.2 cents per litre from the previous quarter. Petrol prices were more expensive in regional areas than the five biggest cities of Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth. The competition regulator also says average retail diesel prices in Australia's five largest cities continued to decrease during the June quarter to similar levels as average retail petrol prices. In June, average retail diesel prices in the five largest cities fell to 181.2 cents a litre, cheaper than average retail petrol prices of 183.7 a litre. ACCC commissioner Anne Brakey explains why: “In the June quarter a number of international factors influenced the fall in diesel prices including further exports of diesel and gasoil from Russia despite sanctions, a decline in North American and European consumption, and an unexpected build-up in diesel inventories." “Retail diesel and petrol prices have trended higher in July and August, following increases in international crude oil and refined diesel and petrol benchmark prices, and a weaker AUD-USD exchange rate."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Petrol prices stable over June quarter before rising

children.content: Petrol prices have been climbing as oil prices have increased.
CommSec says petrol is up by nearly 23 per cent over the year, and by 16 per cent over the past two months.
Although the national average petrol price fell 1.7 cents per litre last week to 201.7 cents a litre.
The ACCC today released its latest petrol monitoring report.
It says retail petrol prices were stable over the June quarter, rising by 0.7 cents per litre from the March quarter to 182.9 cents a litre.

props.alt: Map of Australia showing average retail petrol prices in capital cities

children.content: Petrol prices
(ACCC )
Quarterly average retail petrol prices increased in Canberra, Darwin and Hobart.
Average prices across more than 190 regional locations the ACCC monitors were 185.3 cents per litre, up 2.2 cents per litre from the previous quarter.
Petrol prices were more expensive in regional areas than the five biggest cities of Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth.
The competition regulator also says average retail diesel prices in Australia's five largest cities continued to decrease during the June quarter to similar levels as average retail petrol prices.
In June, average retail diesel prices in the five largest cities fell to 181.2 cents a litre, cheaper than average retail petrol prices of 183.7 a litre.
ACCC commissioner Anne Brakey explains why:
“In the June quarter a number of international factors influenced the fall in diesel prices
including further exports of diesel and gasoil from Russia despite sanctions, a decline in North American and European consumption, and an unexpected build-up in diesel inventories."

“Retail diesel and petrol prices have trended higher in July and August, following increases in international crude oil and refined diesel and petrol benchmark prices, and a weaker AUD-USD exchange rate."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has recouped its early losses and ended in the green. The ASX 200 index rose 0.2 per cent to 7,207 with more sectors higher than lower. The Australian dollar traded in a narrow range after rising 0.9 per cent overnight. Miners and healthcare stocks did the best, while energy and technology stocks weighed on the market. Liontown Resources (-0.3 per cent) fell after news that Gina Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting had increased its stake. Delta Lithium (6.5 per cent) jumped as Perth mining mogul and Mineral Resources boss Chris Ellison joined the board as its non executive chairman, and his lithium chief executive, Josh Thurlow, as a non executive director. Mineral Resources took a 17 per cent stake in Delta Lithium last month as big miners scoop up smaller lithium players. Wireless technology company Etherstack (+36.8%) jumped after signing an agreement with Telstra to trial and evaluate its Mission Critical 3GPP standards compliant Interworking Function technology for use in public safety communications in Australia. ASX 200 best and worst performers: Link Administration: +6 per cent Imugene: +5.1 per cent Pilbara Minerals: +4.3 per cent Syrah Resources: -7.4 per cent Viva Energy: -7.3 per cent BrainChip: -6.8 per cent
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian shares end higher

children.content: The Australian share market has recouped its early losses and ended in the green.
The ASX 200 index rose 0.2 per cent to 7,207 with more sectors higher than lower.
The Australian dollar traded in a narrow range after rising 0.9 per cent overnight.
Miners and healthcare stocks did the best, while energy and technology stocks weighed on the market.
Liontown Resources
(-0.3 per cent) fell after news that Gina Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting had increased its stake.
Delta Lithium
(6.5 per cent) jumped as Perth mining mogul and Mineral Resources boss
Chris Ellison
joined the board as its non executive chairman, and his lithium chief executive, Josh Thurlow, as a non executive director.
Mineral Resources took a 17 per cent stake in Delta Lithium last month as big miners scoop up smaller lithium players.
Wireless technology company
Etherstack
(+36.8%) jumped after signing an agreement with
Telstra
to trial and evaluate its Mission Critical 3GPP standards compliant Interworking Function technology for use in public safety communications in Australia.
ASX 200 best and worst performers:
Link Administration: +6 per cent
Imugene: +5.1 per cent
Pilbara Minerals: +4.3 per cent
Syrah Resources: -7.4 per cent
Viva Energy: -7.3 per cent
BrainChip: -6.8 per cent

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Staying on superannuation, the nation's largest superannuation fund, AustralianSuper, is spending $2.5 billion to buy a minority stake in global data centre firm Vantage Data Centers. The move is the company's first significant investment in data centres, which house servers and hardware equipment. The super fund joins US investment manager Digital Bridge as a key shareholder in Vantage Data's Europe, Middle East and Africa (EMEA) business. Nik Kemp, head of infrastructure at AustralianSuper: "The Vantage EMEA platform is at an exciting point in its history, with a strong pipeline of developments in growing markets across the region. "The Vantage EMEA platform will complement our existing digital infrastructure investments and this acquisition represents an important step for the fund as we build out our infrastructure capability in Europe."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian Super invests in data centres

children.content: Staying on superannuation, the nation's largest superannuation fund, AustralianSuper, is spending $2.5 billion to buy a minority stake in global data centre firm Vantage Data Centers.
The move is the company's first significant investment in data centres, which house servers and hardware equipment.
The super fund joins US investment manager Digital Bridge as a key shareholder in Vantage Data's Europe, Middle East and Africa (EMEA) business.
Nik Kemp, head of infrastructure at AustralianSuper:
"The Vantage EMEA platform is at an exciting point in its history, with a strong pipeline of developments in growing markets across the region.

"The Vantage EMEA platform will complement our existing digital infrastructure investments and this acquisition represents an important step for the fund as we build out our infrastructure capability in Europe."
